1. If the shirt was cotton, then the pants were denim.
2. If the shirt was not cotton, then the pants were not denim.

To determine the validity of the argument, we need to evaluate whether the conclusion logically follows from the premises.

The argument is logically valid if and only if the conclusion follows necessarily from the premises. In other words, if the premises are true, then the conclusion must be true.

| Premise 1 | Premise 2 | Conclusion |
